reasoning:
First off, Netflix sits well outside my Circle of Competence. I built my career focusing on straightforward businesses—coke bottles, insurance premiums, railroad cars—not the complexity of global streaming, heavy content spending and ever-shifting technology platforms. 

Moat: Netflix has scale and a household name, but its pricing power is under siege. Competitors like Disney+, Amazon and Apple TV+ keep chipping away. There’s churn and a constant need to outspend foes on original content. That’s hardly a durable, fortress-like advantage. 

Management: I admire Reed Hastings’ vision, but I’m wary of a management team that plows massive capital into content with uncertain returns. I want owners who earn more than goodwill when they spend a dollar. Here, the track record of converting content dollars into free cash flow doesn’t inspire the same confidence I have in see’s candies or GEICO. 

Financial Health: With no balance sheet or cash-flow details at hand, it’s tough to judge Netflix’s financial fortress. Anecdotally, I know they carry significant debt to finance content, and cash flow has been lumpy. That’s a red flag for me—I like predictability and minimal leverage. 

Valuation: We have zero intrinsic value estimate here. Without a margin of safety, paying up in a business you don’t fully grasp is a recipe for permanent capital loss. 

Long Term Prospects: Twelve years from now, I expect content distribution to look very different. Will Netflix still be on top? It’s anyone’s guess. Contrast that with a business like Coca-Cola, which has quietly increased prices at five-percent-a-year for decades without losing a customer. 

Comparison: I’d rather own a wonderful, simple business I understand with a durable moat and great managers at a fair price than take a flyer here. In short, this one’s a pass for me. I’m not bearish on Netflix investors who understand streaming economics and can value content libraries, but I’m neutral to the idea of betting my capital here.

– Warren Buffett
